Break down walls to build a more connected virtual world

The future of digital experiences is not a single app. It's a network of millions of virtual worlds and digital experiences people visit to play games, socialize and collaborate. Today, most of those experiences are closed and disconnected walled gardens.

Ready Player Me is a cross-game avatar platform for  developers , creators and players. We're on a mission to break down the virtual walls to enable  more open and connected worlds and any digital experience.

How we got here...

The company was started in 2014 by Timmu Tõke (CEO), Rainer Selvet (CTO), Kaspar Tiri (CCO) and Haver Järveoja (COO). The founding team has been working together on avatars for almost 9 years.

The beginnings...

Our first product was a professional, hardware-based 3D scanner. We operated our scanners in public places like airports, museums, and conference halls around the world.

Scan library

We scanned more than 20,000 people and collected a massive database of high-quality face scans in the process.  This proprietary database of face scans allowed us to build a deep-learning solution that creates perfect virtual avatars from a single selfie on any device.

Built on strong partnerships

We spent 4 years custom building avatar systems and avatar tech for enterprise customers like Tencent, Huawei, HTC, Wargaming, Verizon and many others.

Reinventing avatars

We launched Ready Player Me in 2020 with the aim of becoming the default avatar system for the builders, creators and residents of the metaverse.

Adidas Originals Creates World’s First, Personality-Based AI-Generated Avatars

Together with Ready Player Me, adidas Originals created 10M+ unique combinations of AI-generated avatars to promote their Ozworld collection

10

unique combinations available

428

k+

avatars created in the first 10 days

18

k+

avatars redeemed on Ready Player Me

To celebrate the release of their new Ozworld collection, adidas Originals partnered with Jam3 (part of Media.Monks) to build an AI-powered avatar creator based on a personality quiz.

As part of the Ozworld digital experience, users completed a personality quiz. Based on the results, an AI algorithm created a unique avatar inspired by three new Ozworld shoes silhouettes. There were 10 million unique combinations of avatars available. In the first 10 days of the campaign, users have created over 428k avatars.

Each avatar created on the Ozworld platform was fully compatible with thousands of apps and games integrating Ready Player Me avatars. Users could claim the Ozworld avatars and redeem them on the Ready Player Me Hub to access in the future. Users have redeemed over 18,000 avatars.

BMW's Immersive Experiences With 3D Avatars

BMW, one of the world's biggest car manufactures, partnered with Ready Player Me and Journee to create immersive experiences promoting their new and concept vehicles in unique, immersive environments featuring avatars and custom digital outfits.

For the launch of BMW's new iX1 electric vehicle, the company has launched a unique virtual environment letting people discover the car up-close as their Ready Player Me avatar. As a part of the campaign, BMW released branded outfits available to all users of Ready Player Me.

During CES 2023, BMW has unveiled the BMW i Vision Dee, the company's first car with a "digital soul". Dee will let its driver set a personal Ready Player Me avatar that will greet them on the side window when entering the car ‚Äî among other immersive experiences offered by the vehicle. The launch of the BMW i Vision Dee was accompanied by a virtual experience "A Quest to Dee" created by Journee. Users could use their Ready Player Me avatars to explore the world, get to know Dee, and claim an exclusive outfit for their avatar.

Look great anywhere with Tommy Hilfiger's Parallel collection

Parallel Tommy Hilfiger brings the virtual world to life with premium quality fashion to be worn by your avatar and you

1200

400

Parallel was Tommy Hilfiger's first venture into virtual worlds. As part of the campaign, the company launched a collection of digital avatar outfits based on garments sold in Tommy Hilfiger stores, on their website, and at other retailers.

Consumers could preview outfits in the collection one of pre-created Ready Player Me avatars based on models displaying real-life outfits on Tommy Hilfiger's online store.

The digital outfits were available to claim on Ready Player Me for free to the visitors of the Parallel Tommy Hilfiger website. The virtual versions of the garments are compatible with all apps and games using full-body Ready Player Me avatars.
